Article Title: Congress MP claims BJP neta was drunk during Rahul Gandhi's speech
Article Text:
A Congress MP has accused a senior BJP member of attending Lok Sabha proceedings "drunk" during Rahul Gandhi's speech on electoral reforms. The MP cited the individual's "repeated gestures" and "tottering" as evidence, urging the BJP to prevent such incidents. This allegation follows a recent row over a TMC MP allegedly "vaping" in the House, highlighting concerns over parliamentary decorum.

NEW DELHI: Congress MP Sukhdeo Bhagat alleged that a senior BJP member had come to Lok Sabha "drunk" when he tried to disturb Rahul Gandhi's speech during the debate on 'electoral reforms'.Escalating the row triggered by BJP's Anurag Thakur's accusation that a TMC MP was "vaping" in the House Thursday, Bhagat said, "This senior BJP member's video during the proceedings can be checked for his repeated gestures, the way he was tottering, when Rahul Gandhi was giving the speech. It is obvious, and I know for a fact, he was inebriated during proceedings. This is a serious matter, and BJP should ensure it doesn't happen again. " While Bhagat didn't name the MP he was referring to, it was said to be about a minister who made himself conspicuous with his actions during LoP's speech.The Jharkhand MP told reporters it was crucial for parliamentarians to ensure decorum in Lok Sabha. "It should not become a partisan issue with concerns about etiquette only being raised with regard to the opposition," he remarked.He said while he was wondering what to do about the shocking development he witnessed, he was encouraged to speak out after Speaker Om Birla Thursday made his observations about the "vaping" issue and urged members to ensure decorum in the chamber.
Article Summary: Congress MP Sukhdeo Bhagat accuses a senior BJP member of attending Lok Sabha proceedings "drunk" during Rahul Gandhi's speech on electoral reforms. The MP cited the individual's "repeated gestures" and "tottering" as evidence. This allegation follows a recent row over a TMC MP allegedly "vaping" in the House.

Article Title: DK Shivakumar: Karnataka CM-change buzz, DK Shivakumar hosts late-night dinner with 30+ Congress MLAs, ministers in Belagavi
Article Text:
Karnataka deputy CM, ministers, Cong MLAs meet over dinner

'We Are United...Will Go To Delhi If High Command Calls': Siddaramaiah, Shivakumar After Meeting

BENGALURU: Karnataka deputy chief minister DK Shivakumar met with over 30 Congress legislators and ministers for a dinner meeting late Thursday night in Belagavi, amid ongoing speculations about potential leadership changes in the state government.According to news agency PTI sources, dinner gathering included prominent ministers K H Muniyappa, Mankal Vaidya, Dr M C Sudhakar, and several MLAs including N A Haris, Ramesh Bandisiddegowda, H C Balakrishna, Ganesh Hukkeri, Darshan Dhruvanarayana, Ashok Kumar Rai, and K Y Nanjegowda.Expelled BJP MLAs ST Somashekhar and Shivaram Hebbar were also present.This meeting followed a separate dinner hosted by former Belagavi North MLA Feroz Sait the previous day, which was attended by Chief Minister Siddaramaiah and his close associates.While party leaders describe these as casual dinner meetings, they have attracted attention due to the ongoing power dynamics within the ruling party regarding the chief minister position.The timing of these gatherings is significant as they occurred after speculation about a possible change in chief minister when the Congress government completed its half-term on November 20, 2023.The party high command had recently instructed both Siddaramaiah and Shivakumar to meet over breakfast at each other's residences.This move was seen as an attempt to pause the leadership tussle between the two leaders.These breakfast meetings were also interpreted as a signal for Siddaramaiah's continuation as chief minister for the immediate future, particularly before the Belagavi legislature session.The recent developments follow rumors about a possible power-sharing agreement between Siddaramaiah and Shivakumar after Congress won the Assembly election in 2023.
Article Summary: DK Shivakumar met with over 30 Congress legislators and ministers for a dinner meeting late Thursday night in Belagavi. The dinner gathering included prominent ministers K H Muniyappa, Mankal Vaidya, Dr M C Sudhakar, and several MLAs including N A Haris.

Article Title: Kerala local body election results 2025: NDA and LDF neck-and-neck in Thiruvananthapuram corporationâ€”Live Updates
Article Text:
Representative Image

Live Updates:

According to the Trends by the State Election Commission, Kerala, UDF led by the Congress is leading on 387 wards, LDF led by CPI(M) is leading on 283 wards, NDA led by the BJP is leading on 71 wards, and Others are leading on 59 wards in the Kerala local body elections .

LDF leading in Kozhikode corporation and NDA in Thiruvananthapuram.

Breaking: UDF defeats LDF in Palayam ward of Thiruvananthapuram corporation.

LDF leads in 334 grama panchayats, UDF in 296.

By 9.06 am, the NDA lost some momentum, with leads dropping to 10 in gram panchayats, 1 in block panchayat, 4 in municipalities, and 0 in municipal corporations.

Trends at 8.51am indicated the LDF leading in 136 Gram Panchayat seats, while the UDF led in 113. Among 87 municipalities, the LDF and UDF were leading in 29 and 28 seats, respectively.

'PM Modi Hacks Hearts, Not EVM': Kangana Ranaut Lambasts Rahul Gandhi During SIR Debate In Lok Sabha

KOCHI: Counting of votes for 1,199 local bodies in Kerala began at 8 am on Saturday, with postal ballots counted first, followed by EVM votes.The State Election Commission (SEC) reported initial trends showing the ruling LDF, the opposition UDF, and the NDA leading in various gram panchayat, block panchayat, municipality, and corporation wards. Counting is underway at 244 centres and 14 district collectorates.Some issues were reported at a few centres, including Thiruvananthapuram, Palakkad, and Vadakara, over entry of booth agents and candidates.The results are seen as an important indicator ahead of the 2026 Kerala assembly elections, shaping the future campaigning strategies of political parties and fronts in the state.The oath-taking ceremonies for elected panchayat members and municipal councillors will be held at 10 am on December 21, while corporation councillors will take oath at 11am the same day.
Article Summary: Counting of votes for 1,199 local bodies in Kerala began at 8 am on Saturday, with postal ballots counted first, followed by EVM votes. Counting is underway at 244 centres and 14 district collectorates. The results are seen as an important indicator ahead of the 2026 Kerala assembly elections.
